image.altText: A man in a safety mask and goggles works on a countertop with a circular saw, surrounded by dust.

items.synopsis: A new report has called for a ban on all engineered stone in Australia, but governments will not make any changes until they decide on a "national response".

title.children: 'All engineered stone should be prohibited' after surge in silicosis cases, report finds

image.altText: Zak Grieve, wearing a prison ID tag, baseball cap and sunglasses around his neck, sits in front of a wall with art on it.

items.synopsis: Zak Grieve was handed a life sentence, with a non-parole period of 20 years, for a murder he wasn't there for. More than 12 years later, he has been released from prison.

title.children: Zak Grieve released after serving 12 years of life sentence for murder he didn't take part in

image.altText: Large tree stumps with an axe on top.

items.synopsis: Third-generation sawmiller Ian Bradshaw considers himself the custodian of Tasmania's rarest native timber — a job he takes very seriously.

title.children: This timber is so rare, you have to prove you are worthy enough to buy it

image.altText: Police rescue officers in white jumpsuits standing on large rocks at the base of steep cliffs at Vaucluse

items.synopsis: Lilie James worked as a water polo coach at St Andrew's Cathedral School before her body was found on campus in a bathroom in the gym area.

title.children: Body recovered in search for man wanted over woman's 'horrific' death at Sydney school

image.altText: Lilie James, who was found dead at St Andrew's Cathedral School on October 25, 2023, in 2020 in graduation outfit and hat

items.synopsis: The family of the 21-year-old Lilie James, who was found dead inside St Andrew's Cathedral School, release a statement saying she was "vibrant, outgoing, and very much loved".

title.children: 'We are devastated and heartbroken': Lilie James' family release statement after suspected murder

image.altText: China's Premier Li Keqiang points a finger and gestures during a news conference.

items.synopsis: Li Keqiang, China's former premier who served under President Xi Jinping from 2013 until March this year, has died, state media reports.

title.children: China's former premier Li Keqiang dies months after leaving office, state media says

image.altText: Soldiers milling about a tank

items.synopsis: The behind-the-scenes role Qatar is playing is a key factor in why the Israeli army has still not begun a ground invasion of Gaza, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Why isn't the Israeli army invading Gaza? One of the major reasons is Qatar

image.altText: NT Police car flashing lights

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man avoids jail time after pleading guilty to non-fatal strangling and assaulting his former partner, in one of the state's first cases since new laws were brought in.

title.children: Man who strangled ex-partner and told her she 'deserved' it avoids prison

image.altText: Ambulances ramped at the Royal Hobart Hospital

items.synopsis: A parliamentary inquiry into ambulance ramping in Tasmania receives "devastating" submissions, including stories of patients dying in corridors while separated from loved ones, but Premier Jeremy Rockliff says the problems are "not unique" to Tasmania — which he says is "doing well under the circumstances".

title.children: Suicide-risk patient ramped at hospital for so long that mental health order expired, inquiry hears

image.altText: Two men smile in a park

items.synopsis: The deputy mayor of a Sydney council is sacked after trying to amend a motion about the Israel-Gaza conflict, to call out "war crimes" by Israel and hold both sides of the conflict to account "in accordance with international law".

title.children: Deputy mayor sacked after backing move to condemn Israel's bombing of Gaza

image.altText: Two 22-storey sandy coloured apartment high rises in Parramatta street in front

items.synopsis: The undertaking, struck between the NSW building commissioner and a developer in receivership, is the first of its kind and designed to serve as a caution for financiers considering lending to risky developers.

title.children: Buyers of defective apartments allowed to break contracts, recoup deposits in 'quite radical' NSW first

image.altText: Diana stands and smiles with her teenage sons, Harry and William.

items.synopsis: The bumper final season of The Crown has been split into two parts, with the trailer for part one showing the Netflix series getting as close as it can to Princess Diana’s death as the royal family ride the wave of public opinion.

title.children: From a blooming romance to a car chase through Paris, the final season of The Crown charts Diana's doomed destiny

image.altText: A woman with brown hair wearing a sparkly top smiles at camera

items.synopsis: Australian media personality Abbie Chatfield announces she will not be co-hosting the Fridayz Live 2023 Australia and New Zealand concert tour next month, citing sexual harassment allegations against the tour's headline act, US pop star Jason Derulo.

title.children: 'I don't feel comfortable': Abbie Chatfield quits hosting gig over allegations against headline act

image.altText: A dated image of a happy smiling woman.

items.synopsis: A 77-year-old man who cannot be identified for legal reasons is charged by police in Western Australia with the murder of Sharon Fulton, who vanished in 1986 and whose body has never been found.

title.children: Elderly man faces court 37 years after allegedly murdering Perth mother Sharon Fulton

image.altText: Two men in suits outside of a court house

items.synopsis: White supremacists Thomas Sewell and Jacob Hersant are convicted of violent disorder over a 2021 incident where far-right extremists ambushed a group of hikers.

title.children: Neo-Nazis walk free from court, spared further jail time over attack on Victorian hikers

image.altText: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange

items.synopsis: The ASX 200 is up on lithium, mining and a supermarket chain's good fortune. But a jump in the cost of production inputs threatens to keep inflation higher for longer. Follow the latest financial news with insights from the ABC's specialist business reporters on our live blog.

title.children: Australian share market rises, producer prices jump and politicians talk tax in Canberra

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 has defied a negative lead from Wall Street to close higher, despite widespread bets of a Reserve Bank cash rate increase on November 7. The benchmark index finished up 0.2% at 6,827 points. The latest odds (via Refinitiv) of an increase to the cash rate on the first Tuesday in November were 56%, having fluctuated wildly during the week on economic data and two appearances by the new RBA governor Michele Bullock. Perhaps the prospect of higher rates contributed to a bad day for the local tech sector which, along with healthcare and education, posted the biggest declines. The best gains came from two sectors relatively unaffected by interest rates and the consumer cut backs associated with rate rises — consumer non-cyclicals and utilities. Coles was a solid contributor to that gain for consumer essentials stocks, up 2.1% to $15.29 as the market digested its sales results released yesterday. Harvey Norman surprised the market with a first quarter sales update today, and it wasn't a pleasant one. Sales were off more than 9 per cent and foot traffic in its stores down more than double that as consumers cut back in response to the rising cost of living and interest payments. Despite this, Harvey Norman shares ended 4.8% higher at $3.72 after the company said it would buy back up to 10 per cent of its shares. The other top gainers today were: Silver Lake Resources +7.7% to $1.05 Champion Iron +6.9% to $6.94 Alumina Ltd +5.2% to $0.81 Coronado Global Resources +3.8% to $1.765 The biggest losers on the ASX 200 were: Brambles Ltd -5.7% to $13.19 Healius Ltd -4.9% to $1.835 Steadfast Group -4.3% to $5.35 Resmed -4% to $21.56 AUB Group -3.4% to $26.57 And that's it from me for this week, but I'll be back on the blog on Monday morning. Catch you then.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes higher as Harvey Norman shrugs off sales slump to surge

children.content: The ASX 200 has defied a negative lead from Wall Street to close higher, despite widespread bets of a Reserve Bank cash rate increase on November 7.
The benchmark index finished
up 0.2% at 6,827 points
The
latest odds (via Refinitiv) of an
increase to the cash rate on the first Tuesday in November were 56%
, having fluctuated wildly during the week on economic data and two appearances by the new RBA governor Michele Bullock.
Perhaps the prospect of higher rates contributed to a
bad day for the local tech sector
which, along with
healthcare and education
, posted the biggest declines.
The
best gains
came from two sectors relatively unaffected by interest rates and the consumer cut backs associated with rate rises —
consumer non-cyclicals and utilities
Coles
was a solid contributor to that gain for consumer essentials stocks,
as the market digested its sales results released yesterday.
Harvey Norman
surprised the market with a first quarter sales update today, and it wasn't a pleasant one.
Sales were off more than 9 per cent
and foot traffic in its stores down more than double that as consumers cut back in response to the rising cost of living and interest payments.
Despite this,
Harvey Norman shares ended 4.8% higher at $3.72
after the company said it would buy back up to 10 per cent of its shares.
The other
top gainers
today were:
Silver Lake Resources +7.7% to $1.05
Champion Iron +6.9% to $6.94
Alumina Ltd +5.2% to $0.81
Coronado Global Resources +3.8% to $1.765
The
biggest losers
on the ASX 200 were:
Brambles Ltd -5.7% to $13.19
Healius Ltd -4.9% to $1.835
Steadfast Group -4.3% to $5.35
Resmed -4% to $21.56
AUB Group -3.4% to $26.57
And that's it from me for this week, but I'll be back on the blog on Monday morning. Catch you then.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In an interview focused on the housing affordability crisis, Melbourne radio 3AW host Neil Mitchell quizzed NAB CEO Ross McEwen, who attributed the price and rent rises to a shortage of homes due to both development approval delays and to a "catch-up" surge in migration after COVID. Here's a key exchange in a transcript sent out by NAB: NM: I was talking to Abdul Rizvi this week, former deputy secretary of the Department of Immigration. He's done the figures, which he used to do in government, and he worked for both sides and he said the net gain in the immigration in Australia this year is 500,000 people. And what do you say? Well, let's, let's assume they're couples. That's 250,000. RM: Yeah. NM: And we're building 175,000 houses. RM: And there's our problem. Now, just to be fair though, we lost something like 600,000 people out of the country through the COVID period. So we're not … NM: It's catch-up. RM: Yeah, it's catch-up, but it is showing the issue that if we want to keep growing this country — which I think we do need to keep growing this country — we need housing. NM: But nobody can tell me what the correct growth rate is. Nobody can tell me, and I don't think anybody's even assessing, what the correct immigration rate is. This was his point, he said it used to be about 130[000], maybe 150[000] to 170[000] is right. RM: Yeah. NM: 500[000] isn't. RM: No. NM: But we don't know. RM: But that 500[000] is a lot of catch-up and we did need to have a catch-up because we couldn't find people in small-medium sized businesses to work. If you got out into the agricultural sector, they were struggling to get people out onto the farms and the orchards and the like, so we needed to catch up and get those people back in. I think we're pretty well getting close to that. Now we need to work through what is the right immigration level for this country. Later in the interview, Mr McEwen also acknowledged that migration was keeping Australia out of recession, with per capita GDP going backwards for the past two quarters. "You've also got to go back to the point of immigration is very helpful at a time of when things are slowing down, because whoever comes into the country, they need somewhere to live, they probably need transport. They use all the things you and I do. That keeps an economy going."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB CEO says current migration levels are contributing to the housing crisis

children.content: In an interview focused on the housing affordability crisis,
Melbourne radio 3AW host Neil Mitchell quizzed NAB CEO Ross McEwen
, who attributed the price and rent rises to a shortage of homes due to both development approval delays and to a "catch-up" surge in migration after COVID.
Here's a key exchange in a transcript sent out by NAB:

NM: I was talking to Abdul Rizvi this week, former deputy secretary of the Department of Immigration. He's done the figures, which he used to do in government, and he worked for both sides and he said the net gain in the immigration in Australia this year is 500,000 people. And what do you say? Well, let's, let's assume they're couples. That's 250,000.
RM: Yeah.
NM: And we're building 175,000 houses.
RM: And there's our problem. Now, just to be fair though, we lost something like 600,000 people out of the country through the COVID period. So we're not …
NM: It's catch-up.
RM: Yeah, it's catch-up, but it is showing the issue that if we want to keep growing this country — which I think we do need to keep growing this country — we need housing.

NM: But nobody can tell me what the correct growth rate is. Nobody can tell me, and I don't think anybody's even assessing, what the correct immigration rate is. This was his point, he said it used to be about 130[000], maybe 150[000] to 170[000] is right.
RM: Yeah.
RM: No.
NM: But we don't know.

RM: But that 500[000] is a lot of catch-up and we did need to have a catch-up because we couldn't find people in small-medium sized businesses to work. If you got out into the agricultural sector, they were struggling to get people out onto the farms and the orchards and the like, so we needed to catch up and get those people back in. I think we're pretty well getting close to that. Now we need to work through what is the right immigration level for this country.
Later in the interview, Mr McEwen also acknowledged that migration was keeping Australia out of recession, with per capita GDP going backwards for the past two quarters.

"You've also got to go back to the point of immigration is very helpful at a time of when things are slowing down, because whoever comes into the country, they need somewhere to live, they probably need transport. They use all the things you and I do. That keeps an economy going."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Left-of-centre think tank The Australia Institute is hosting a revenue summit in Canberra today. Unsurprisingly, given the hosts, the key theme of the summit was the urgent need to raise more revenue to pay for government services. Probably the most interesting speaker was former finance department boss Michael Keating (no relation to former PM Paul). He says Australia needs to dramatically increase its tax take, rather than cut it (as will happen when the already legislated stage three income tax cuts take effect next July). "Even if Australia increased its taxation revenue by as much as another 4% of GDP, as I've suggested is needed, I contend that that would not harm economic growth. "Taxation in Australia would still only be raising about the same amount of revenue relative to GDP as the OECD average, and Australian taxation would still be lower than in Canada and the UK." And here's how he thinks it could be done. "First: a high priority would be to rely more on those taxes which improve efficiency, such as a carbon tax, congestion charging and substituting a land tax for stamp duty. "Second: Australia raises relatively little from its GST compared to other countries. [It] would be possible and arguably desirable to raise more by a combination of broadening the GST tax base and raising the GST tax rate. "Third: resource rent tax. So the community shares some of the super profits that mining companies can make due to fortuitous circumstances not from their own effort or initiative. "Fourth: the avoidance of company tax has become an industry. As I said, I'm not an expert, but urge close consideration of Ross Garnaut's proposal to substitute a tax on corporate cash flows for the present company tax. "Fifth: loopholes in the personal income tax system, such as inadequate rate of capital gains taxation and negative gearing should similarly be closed. "Sixth, and finally, we need more progressive income tax rates. The starting point should be to at least adjust the stage three tax cuts ." If you don't know what the stage three tax cuts are, I did a handy primer video earlier this year with Angelique Lu. That last proposal also got support from independent MPs Monique Ryan and Dai Le. "For the government, they really can't go ahead with it, shouldn't go ahead with it," said Dai Le, the member for Fowler, a traditionally Labor electorate in south-west Sydney. "And think about it, especially for a Labor government by the way. Labor is supposed to be for the working Australians, right?" Ms Ryan, who defeated previous treasurer Josh Frydenberg in the wealthy Melbourne electorate of Kooyong, may not be popular with some of her high-income constituents for also backing the wind-back of stage three. "The 2019 stage three tax cuts were a booby trap for our economy," she argued. "Led by Malcolm Turnbull, and by Scott Morrison and Josh Frydenberg, they were the wrong policy at the wrong time then, and worse now. "They will be inflationary, they'll suck revenue out of a tax system at a time when we need more revenue to set up … a country for the future to drive our transition to a new clean energy economy and to find the revenue that we need for aged care, child care, disability care and medical care. "This at a time when debt costs cost us more to service our debt than we have for a long, long time." Her suggestion? To retain the 37% tax rate on each dollar earned between $120,001-200,000, which is being abolished as part of stage three. I went down to Canberra to cover last year's event, and that was one of the key suggestions put forward by some of the tax experts I spoke to then.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Talking tax in Canberra

featuredLink.title: Two tax changes could raise more than $20 billion a year and halve the deficit, but they're off the table this budget

children.content: Left-of-centre think tank
The Australia Institute is hosting a revenue summit in Canberra
today.
Unsurprisingly, given the hosts, the key theme of the summit was the urgent need to raise more revenue to pay for government services.
Probably the most interesting speaker was
former finance department boss Michael Keating
(no relation to former PM Paul).
He says Australia needs to dramatically increase its tax take, rather than cut it (as will happen when the already legislated stage three income tax cuts take effect next July).
"Even if Australia increased its taxation revenue by as much as another 4% of GDP, as I've suggested is needed, I contend that that would not harm economic growth.
"Taxation in Australia would still only be raising about the same amount of revenue relative to GDP as the OECD average, and Australian taxation would still be lower than in Canada and the UK."
And here's how he thinks it could be done.
"First: a high priority would be to rely more on those taxes which improve efficiency, such as a
carbon tax, congestion charging and substituting a land tax for stamp duty
"Second: Australia raises relatively little from its GST compared to other countries. [It] would be possible and arguably desirable to raise more by a combination of
broadening the GST tax base and raising the GST tax rate
"Third:
resource rent tax
. So the community shares some of the super profits that mining companies can make due to fortuitous circumstances not from their own effort or initiative.
"Fourth: the
avoidance of company tax
has become an industry. As I said, I'm not an expert, but urge close consideration of Ross Garnaut's proposal to
substitute a tax on corporate cash flows for the present company tax
"Fifth:
loopholes in the personal income tax system
, such as inadequate rate of
capital gains taxation and negative gearing
should similarly be closed.
"Sixth, and finally, we need
more progressive income tax rates
. The starting point should be to at least
adjust the stage three tax cuts
If you don't know what the
stage three tax cuts
are, I did a handy primer video earlier this year with
Angelique Lu
That last proposal also got support from independent MPs
Monique Ryan and Dai Le
"For the government, they really can't go ahead with it, shouldn't go ahead with it," said Dai Le, the member for Fowler, a traditionally Labor electorate in south-west Sydney.
"And think about it, especially for a Labor government by the way. Labor is supposed to be for the working Australians, right?"

Ms Ryan, who defeated previous treasurer Josh Frydenberg in the wealthy Melbourne electorate of Kooyong, may not be popular with some of her high-income constituents for also backing the wind-back of stage three.
"The 2019 stage three tax cuts were a booby trap for our economy," she argued.
"Led by Malcolm Turnbull, and by Scott Morrison and Josh Frydenberg, they were the wrong policy at the wrong time then, and worse now.

"They will be inflationary, they'll suck revenue out of a tax system at a time when we need more revenue to set up … a country for the future to drive our transition to a new clean energy economy and to find the revenue that we need for aged care, child care, disability care and medical care.
"This at a time when debt costs cost us more to service our debt than we have for a long, long time."
Her suggestion? To
retain the 37% tax rate
on each dollar earned between $120,001-200,000, which is being abolished as part of stage three.
I went down to Canberra to cover last year's event, and that was one of the key suggestions put forward by some of the tax experts I spoke to then.

image.altText: Small flames coming from a box next to solar panels on a roof

items.synopsis: In the decade since Emerald's Sharron Booth first installed solar panels there have been changes to how their isolators are kept safe. That became all too apparent when flames engulfed part of her rooftop system one recent weekday morning.

title.children: Family's rooftop solar fire a warning to regularly check panels

image.altText: A seal on a beach with a rope wrapped tightly around its neck.

items.synopsis: A ranger says a female long nosed fur seal wouldn't have survived much longer had rescuers not been able to remove the rope that was cutting into its neck.

title.children: Wildlife rangers urge public to be responsible with waste after seal freed from rope

image.altText: A lobster being held about to be measured

items.synopsis: Air gun testing critical to Western Australia's offshore oil, gas and energy ambitions is "dazing" the state's valuable western rock lobsters, a new study finds.

title.children: Lobsters left 'concussed' and potentially dead after seismic testing vital to offshore energy industries

image.altText: Black and white image of john lennon, paul mccartner, ringo starr and george harrison standing together in the 1960s.

items.synopsis: The Beatles release their "final ever" song at 1am next Friday, Australian time, over 43 years after the passing of singer and the song's writer John Lennon.

title.children: 'Very emotional': New Beatles song to drop, featuring all four members, thanks to AI

image.altText: Greyhounds running on a track.

items.synopsis: Thirty dogs have been injured and two euthanased in the 10 race meetings since a trial began of a new safety device, the double-arm lure, designed to encourage dogs to run straighter.

title.children: Two greyhounds euthanased, one injured during race featuring new safety device

image.altText: A photo of a person looking at a computer screen showing the AHM car insurance quote landing page

items.synopsis: Insurance company ahm has taken down an online quoting tool after a customer's private details were seen by a person in another state trying to fill in a form.

title.children: Days after Noelene filled out an online form, a stranger told her they'd seen all her details

image.altText: Outside of the Berri Magistrates Court, the sky is blue and the sign is dark brown.

items.synopsis: Police allege a 55-year-old man grabbed his crotch while approaching a 15-year-old girl in Berri and was seen "shaking his penis and winking" at three girls aged 12 to 13 in Loxton.

title.children: Police allege foreign holidaymaker 'tried to grab' Riverland schoolgirl

image.altText: Packed Sydney train

items.synopsis: Trains were stopped at platforms or between stations about 10:20am on Friday due to the error, according to Sydney Trains.

title.children: Delays expected on Sydney's train network 'well into peak' after communication issue

image.altText: an adult daughter and her elderly mother standing beside each other looking straight at the camera with straight faces

items.synopsis: Bushfires continue to burn across southern Queensland with 32 homes and more than a dozen other structures destroyed with multiple new fires ignited after storm activity overnight.

title.children: 'My house is pretty much flat': Tara mum 'numb' after home destroyed by bushfires

image.altText: A water bomber plane drops water on grass fire

items.synopsis: Firefighters are battling major blazes around the outback city where a water bombing plane has been flown in for the first time to assist.

title.children: Campers evacuated, mines under threat as out-of-control fires surround Mount Isa

image.altText: A bushfire raging in NSW

items.synopsis: Up to 100 millimetres of rain has fallen over a wide range of northern New South Wales reducing the number of fires that have been burning for days.

title.children: Northern NSW breathes a sigh of relief as heavy rain soaks fire grounds and brings some drought relief

image.altText: Two smiling twin women with a blue background.

items.synopsis: Carlie Eileen Richards was allegedly driving at excessive speed and had methamphetamine in her system at the time of the crash on Adelaide's Port River Expressway.

title.children: Driver pleads not guilty to causing crash that killed woman and injured twin sister

image.altText: five colourful vapes standing on a black-coloured counter

items.synopsis: Accompanied by Australian Border Force officers and tax officials, Taskforce Viper police have raided outlets in Shepparton, Seymour, Yarrawonga, and Ballarat, seizing more than $2 million worth of vapes, cigarettes, loose tobacco, and cash.

title.children: 40,000 vapes, 611,833 cigarettes seized, and six arrested in Victorian illicit tobacco shop raids

image.altText: Black and white photos of bare-chested man who leans over and sings into a microphone.

items.synopsis: Once labelled the "most dangerous band" in the world, Mutiny in Heaven tells the story of The Birthday Party.

title.children: The true story of Nick Cave and the group once labelled the most dangerous band in the world

image.altText: Alleged Northern Territory escapee Jermaine Austral in security vision from December 2016.

items.synopsis: Police are searching for 27-year-old Jermaine Austral, who they believe has fled to bushland in Batchelor in the Northern Territory.

title.children: Manhunt underway for fugitive believed to be hiding in NT bush

image.altText: Jeep car held by a crane with doors taken off, writing all over it and people standing by watching it be destroyed.

items.synopsis: A Queensland man who made international headlines after pulling apart then setting fire to his faulty Jeep welcomes the importer's new commitment to better handle customer complaints.

title.children: Man who famously destroyed his $49K Jeep finds new ACCC probe 'surprising'

image.altText: Kamala Harris speaks at a podium with Australian and US flags behind. Anthony Albanese, Antony Blinken are next to her

items.synopsis: Australia's gun laws prove the US doesn't have to live with its senseless mass shootings, America's vice-president says, as police continue searching for the bowling alley gunman who killed 18 people in Maine.

title.children: Vice-President Kamala Harris points to Australia's gun laws after 18 killed in Maine shooting

image.altText: A small child's arms from the elbow down playing an upright piano with both hands.

items.synopsis: Are you musical because it's in your genes, or is it from the environment you grew up in? A new scientific review is trying to answer this age-old question.

title.children: Nature or nurture? The jury is still out on where musical talent comes from

image.altText: A woman wearing a purple striped head scarf yells behind men wearing POLIZEI vests

items.synopsis: While Europe's leaders support Israel's right to respond to Hamas aggression, their citizens are divided, with tensions boiling over and giving rise to Islamophobic and anti-Semitic hate crimes and hostilities.

title.children: 'Things can become really dangerous': How the ripple effects of the Israel-Gaza war are being felt in Europe
